text: I've come here to Cairo to seek a new
beginning between the United States and
Muslims around the world one based on
mutual interest and mutual respect in
his forceful but nuanced speech at Cairo
University President Obama called for
alliances with Muslims but also pledged
to confront violent extremism in Ankara
I made clear that America is not and
never will be at war with Islam we will
however relentlessly confront violent
extremists who pose a grave threat to
our security Jeff Zeleny White House
reporter for The New York Times is
traveling with the president and
explains what the White House had hoped
to accomplish President Obama called for
a new beginning today in relations with
the United States and the Muslim world
in doing so he opened up one of the
biggest gambits of his young presidency
when President Obama walked into the
hall and Cairo University today thank
you should run the audience applauded
and greeted his words with deep respect
but more important in the eyes of the
White House was how this was being
received in the wider Muslim world what
President Obama was trying to do today
was use his personal connection his deep
biography to connect with Muslims and
signify a sharp break from President
Bush notably he did not use president
george w bush's name one time but he
said the United States will use
different ideals they will not use the
same policies that the George W Bush did
after the Iraq war I also believe that
events in Iraq have reminded America of
the need to use diplomacy and build
international consensus to resolve our
problems whenever possible all in all
this speech highly anticipated high
expectations it's far too early to say
if this will be worth the risk that mr.
Obama made coming here
but what was the reaction to the
president's speech across the Middle
East and especially on the streets of
Cairo Michael slackman Middle East
bureau chief for The New York Times
spokes with some local Egyptians to get
their views I spent the time of the
speech with about 20 men in a coffee
house in a poor neighborhood called blue
locks the mood in the coffee house was
almost giddy because the men there said
they were accustomed to being demonized
by the President and by Westerners so to
have Barack Obama in their city they
felt was an extraordinary outreach they
were thrilled that the president spoke
eloquently about Islam and actually
quoted from the Quran the enduring faith
of over a billion people is so much
bigger than the narrow hatred of a few
Islam is not part of the problem in
combating violent extremism it is an
important part of promoting peace they
were disappointed and in some cases
turned off by his attempt to create
balance between the Palestinians and the
Israelis but if we see this conflict
only from one side or the other then we
will be blind to the truth the only
resolution is for the aspirations of
both sides to be met through two states
where Israelis and Palestinians each
live in peace and security hit the gavel
what I liked was that his speech
referred to the establishment of a
Palestinian state he's the first
American president to talk honestly and
at the same time clearly he left a good
impression among the Arab nation finally
and the speech was over the big question
hanging over everything was now what his
remarks were well received but they want
to see implementation I think that word
should be implemented and not left
merely a speech no single speech can
eradicate years of mistrust but I am
convinced that in order to move forward
there must be a sustained effort to
listen to each other to learn from each
other to respect one another and to seek
common ground as the Holy Quran tells us
be conscious of God and speak always the
truth
you
